questions.text: Which of the following is the largest DNA virus?
questions.solution:
Poxvirus is recognized as the largest DNA virus. It belongs to the Poxviridae family and is notable for its complex and large brick-shaped structure. The genome of Poxviruses is linear double-stranded DNA (dsDNA), which can be as large as 200-300 kilobase pairs, making it significantly larger than other DNA viruses. The Poxvirus family includes viruses that cause diseases such as smallpox and cowpox.


Other DNA viruses mentioned:

  • Adenovirus: Medium-sized DNA virus, known for causing respiratory infections and conjunctivitis.
  • Herpesvirus: A family of large DNA viruses that include herpes simplex, varicella-zoster (causes chickenpox), and Epstein-Barr virus, but not as large as Poxvirus.
  • Parvovirus: The smallest DNA virus, with a single-stranded DNA (ssDNA) genome. It is known for causing fifth disease in children.

Key Takeaway:
Poxvirus is the largest DNA virus, distinguished by its size and complex structure. Understanding the size and structure of viruses helps in identifying their capabilities and the diseases they may cause.

Note : parvovirus is the smallest DNA virus

CDC Reference: CDC - Smallpox Overview

questions.text: Which of the following viruses is a segmented RNA virus?
questions.solution:
Rotavirus, a member of the Reoviridae family, is an RNA virus that has a segmented genome. Segmented RNA viruses have their genetic material divided into distinct segments, each coding for different proteins. Rotavirus has a double-stranded RNA (dsRNA) genome, with 11 segments in total. This segmentation is crucial because it allows for genetic reassortment, a process where segments from different strains of the virus can mix and produce new viral combinations. This can lead to variations in virulence, immune escape, and epidemiological properties.

Other viruses mentioned:

  • Hepatitis B: A DNA virus, not an RNA virus, and does not have a segmented genome.
  • Rabies virus: A single-stranded RNA virus, belonging to the Rhabdoviridae family, but it has a non-segmented genome.
  • Measles virus: A single-stranded RNA virus, part of the Paramyxoviridae family, also with a non-segmented genome.

Key Takeaway:

Mnemonics

Segmented RNA viruses (BIRA)

  • Bunya,
  • Influenza,
  • Rota,
  • Arena(LCM i.e. lymphocytic chorio-meningitis virus)

Segmented RNA viruses, like Rotavirus, have genomes that are divided into multiple segments. This segmentation is essential for genetic reassortment, which contributes to viral diversity and can affect vaccine design and effectiveness.

CDC Reference: CDC - Rotavirus

questions.text: Which of the following viruses is associated with respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) infections?
questions.solution:
Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV) is a member of the Paramyxoviridae family, which includes viruses responsible for causing respiratory infections, particularly in infants and young children. RSV is a leading cause of bronchiolitis and pneumonia in children under one year of age. The virus is characterized by its ability to cause cells to merge and form syncytia (giant cells), which is a hallmark of RSV infection.

Other families mentioned:

  • Orthomyxoviridae: This family includes the influenza viruses, which are responsible for flu pandemics, but not RSV.
  • Togaviridae: A family of RNA viruses that include Rubella virus, which causes German measles, but not RSV.
  • Rhabdoviridae: This family includes the Rabies virus, which causes rabies, but it is not associated with RSV.

Key Takeaway:

RSV is a major cause of respiratory infections in young children and belongs to the Paramyxoviridae family. Understanding the family of viruses helps in diagnosing and developing appropriate treatments and preventive measures for related diseases.

Members of paramyxoviridae:

Measles, mumps, RSV, Hendra virus, nipah virus

CDC Reference:

CDC - RSV (Respiratory Syncytial Virus)

questions.text: What is the shape of the influenza virus?
questions.solution:
A) Helical

  • Explanation: Helical viruses have a shape where the nucleic acid is wrapped around a cylindrical protein coat, forming a helical structure. This shape is common in viruses like the Tobacco Mosaic Virus and some types of RNA viruses, but influenza is not one of them.

B) Icosahedral

  • Explanation: Icosahedral viruses have a shape characterized by 20 equilateral triangular faces, 12 vertices, and 30 edges. Examples include adenoviruses and some types of DNA viruses. Influenza viruses do not exhibit this symmetry.

C) Complex

  • Explanation: Complex viruses have more elaborate structures and do not fit into the simple helical or icosahedral categories. Bacteriophages, with their complex structure including a head and tail, are an example. Influenza viruses are not classified as complex.

D) Spherical

  • Explanation: Influenza viruses are classified as spherical in shape. They are enveloped viruses, meaning they have a lipid membrane surrounding their protein coat. This spherical shape is characteristic of many enveloped viruses, including influenza.

Key Notes:

  • Influenza viruses belong to the Orthomyxoviridae family and have a spherical shape due to their lipid envelope.
  • The spherical structure helps in the virus's ability to interact with host cell membranes.
  • Influenza viruses are further classified based on their surface proteins, hemagglutinin (HA) and neuraminidase (NA), which are crucial for their function and classification.

CDC Reference: For more detailed information on the structure and classification of influenza viruses, refer to the CDC's page on influenza: CDC Influenza Virus Structure.

questions.text: Which virus is known for its bullet-shaped morphology?
questions.solution:
• The Rabies virus is known for its bullet-shaped morphology. This distinctive shape is associated with its neurotropic properties and is crucial for diagnosing rabies infection.

STRUCTURE OF RABV


  • Other shapes mentioned:
    • HIV: Exhibits a conical or pyramidal shape.
    • Ebola Virus: Characterized by a filamentous, thread-like structure.
    • Adenovirus :Space vehicle shaped


Key Takeaway:

  • Recognizing the bullet shape of the Rabies virus aids in diagnosing rabies and understanding its impact on the nervous system.

CDC Reference: CDC - Rabies Virus

choices.text: The envelope is derived from the virus's capsid and provides rigidity to the virus.
The envelope is made up of lipoprotein subunits called peplomere, where the lipid part is derived from the host cell membrane and the protein part is virus-derived.
Enveloped viruses are generally heat-resistant and less sensitive to ether.
Enveloped viruses are non-pleomorphic and have a uniform shape.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about enveloped viruses?
questions.solution:
• Enveloped viruses have a lipid bilayer derived from the host cell membrane, with viral proteins integrated into this envelope. This structure contributes to their sensitivity to ether and heat, as well as their pleomorphic nature.
  • Other statements:
    • A: The envelope is not derived from the capsid but from the host cell membrane.
    • C: Enveloped viruses are generally heat-labile and ether-sensitive.
    • D: Enveloped viruses are pleomorphic, meaning they can have various shapes.
  • Key Takeaway:
    • Understanding the composition of the viral envelope is crucial for studying viral infection mechanisms and developing antiviral treatments.

CDC Reference: CDC - Enveloped Viruses

questions.text: Which of the following virus families are considered non-enveloped and heat-stable?
questions.solution:
• Non-enveloped viruses are generally more resistant to environmental factors such as heat and ether. The listed families (Picornaviridae, Astroviridae, Reoviridae, Caliciviridae) are known for their non-enveloped, heat-stable nature.
  • Other families mentioned:
    • A: Includes enveloped viruses like Adenoviridae and Papillomaviridae.
    • C: Includes enveloped viruses such as Herpesviridae and Orthomyxoviridae.
    • D: Includes enveloped viruses like Flaviviridae and Togaviridae.

Non enveloped virus list:

Key Takeaway:

  • Identifying non-enveloped virus families helps in understanding their stability and resistance to environmental conditions.

CDC Reference: CDC - Non-Enveloped Viruses

choices.text: Non-enveloped viruses are sensitive to ether and heat-labile.
Non-enveloped viruses have a lipid bilayer derived from the host cell membrane.
Non-enveloped viruses are ether-resistant, heat-stable, and non-pleomorphic.
Non-enveloped viruses have peplomeres made from lipoprotein subunits.

questions.text: Which property distinguishes non-enveloped viruses from enveloped viruses?
questions.solution:
• Non-enveloped viruses lack the lipid bilayer found in enveloped viruses, making them resistant to ether and more stable in heat. They are also typically non-pleomorphic, meaning they have a more uniform shape.
  • Other properties:
    • A: Enveloped viruses are sensitive to ether and heat-labile.
    • B: The lipid bilayer is a characteristic of enveloped viruses.
    • D: Peplomeres are components of the envelope in enveloped viruses.
  • Key Takeaway:
    • Understanding the properties of non-enveloped viruses is important for their classification and treatment strategies.

CDC Reference: CDC - Virus Classification

questions.text: Which of the following virus families is classified as a non-enveloped RNA virus?
questions.solution:
• Picornaviridae is a family of non-enveloped RNA viruses, which includes viruses like poliovirus and rhinovirus. The other options are DNA virus families.
  • Option A, B, D are examples of DNA

Key Takeaway:

It's crucial to identify non-enveloped RNA viruses like Picornaviridae because they have different properties and are associated with specific diseases compared to non-enveloped DNA viruses.

CDC Reference: CDC - Picornaviruses

questions.text: Which virus family is known for containing non-enveloped DNA viruses?
questions.solution:
A) Astroviridae:

Justification: Astroviridae consists of non-enveloped RNA viruses, not DNA viruses. These viruses are primarily associated with gastroenteritis and are not linked to DNA viral diseases. They are discussed in CDC resources in the context of gastroenteritis.

CDC Reference: CDC - Astroviruses

B) Reoviridae:

Justification: Reoviridae includes non-enveloped RNA viruses, such as rotavirus, which are known for causing gastroenteritis. They are not DNA viruses and are not related to the Papillomaviridae family.

CDC Reference: CDC - Rotavirus

C) Papillomaviridae:

Justification: Papillomaviridae is indeed a family of non-enveloped DNA viruses. This family includes human papillomavirus (HPV), which is known for causing warts and is associated with various cancers, including cervical cancer. This family is correctly identified as a non-enveloped DNA virus.

CDC Reference: CDC - HPV (Human Papillomavirus)

D) Caliciviridae:

Justification: Caliciviridae includes non-enveloped RNA viruses, such as noroviruses, which cause gastroenteritis. This family does not contain DNA viruses and is not related to Papillomaviridae.

CDC Reference: CDC - Noroviruses

Key Takeaway:

  • Recognizing Papillomaviridae as a non-enveloped DNA virus is important for diagnosing diseases such as warts and cervical cancer, which are associated with this virus family.

CDC Reference: CDC - Papillomaviruses

questions.text: Which of the following families includes non-enveloped RNA viruses that cause gastroenteritis?
questions.solution:
• Reoviridae is a family of non-enveloped RNA viruses that includes rotavirus, a major cause of gastroenteritis. The other options either include DNA viruses or non-gastroenteritis related RNA viruses.

Key Takeaway:

  • Identifying Reoviridae as a family of non-enveloped RNA viruses associated with gastroenteritis is essential for understanding and managing outbreaks of this illness, especially in children.
  • Rotavirus vaccination is associated with intussusception.

CDC Reference: CDC - Rotavirus

questions.text: Which virus family is a non-enveloped DNA virus known for causing respiratory infections?
questions.solution:
A) Papillomaviridae:

Justification: Papillomaviridae consists of non-enveloped DNA viruses, including human papillomavirus (HPV), which are primarily known for causing warts and various cancers, such as cervical cancer. They are not associated with respiratory infections.

B) Astroviridae:

Justification: Astroviridae are non-enveloped RNA viruses primarily associated with gastroenteritis, not respiratory infections. They are known to cause stomach illnesses and are not involved in respiratory disease.

C) Adenoviridae:

Justification: Adenoviridae is the correct answer. This family includes non-enveloped DNA viruses that are known to cause a range of respiratory infections, such as the common cold, bronchitis, and conjunctivitis. Adenoviruses are common causes of respiratory illness, especially in children.

D) Caliciviridae:

Justification: Caliciviridae includes non-enveloped RNA viruses like noroviruses, which are primarily associated with gastroenteritis. They are not typically involved in respiratory infections.

Key Takeaway:

  • Knowing that Adenoviridae is a non-enveloped DNA virus associated with respiratory infections helps in diagnosing and treating conditions like colds and conjunctivitis.

CDC Reference: CDC - Adenoviruses

questions.text: Which of the following is a non-enveloped RNA virus that causes common colds?
questions.solution:
A) Caliciviridae:

Justification: While Caliciviridae includes noroviruses, which are non-enveloped RNA viruses, they are primarily associated with gastroenteritis, not respiratory infections such as the common cold.

B) Picornaviridae:

Justification: Picornaviridae is the correct answer. rhinoviruses, which are well-known non-enveloped RNA viruses responsible for the majority of common colds. This family includes are stable and can cause upper respiratory tract infections.

C) Reoviridae:

Justification: Reoviridae includes rotaviruses, which are non-enveloped RNA viruses, but they primarily cause gastroenteritis rather than common colds. Rotaviruses are notable for causing severe diarrhea, especially in children.

D) Papillomaviridae:

Justification: Papillomaviridae consists of non-enveloped DNA viruses, such as human papillomavirus (HPV), which is associated with warts and certain cancers. This family does not include RNA viruses and is not related to respiratory infections.

Key Takeaway:

  • Recognizing Picornaviridae as a family of non-enveloped RNA viruses responsible for common colds is important for understanding the epidemiology of respiratory infections and managing their treatment.

Reference: CDC - Rhinoviruses

questions.text: Which of the following steps in viral replication involves the specific interaction between viral particles and host cell receptors?
questions.solution:
A) Penetration: This step follows adsorption and involves the entry of the virus into the host cell.

B) Adsorption: This is the initial step where the virus binds specifically to receptors on the host cell surface. It is a crucial and specific step for determining the host range and tissue tropism of the virus.

C) Uncoating: Involves the release of viral genetic material from the capsid after the virus has entered the host cell. Bacteriophages do not go through this step.

D) Maturation and Assembly: This is the stage where new viral particles are assembled and mature, not where initial attachment occurs.

Key Takeaway:

  • Understanding adsorption is important for determining how viruses enter host cells and which cells are susceptible to infection.

CDC Reference: CDC - General Information about Viruses

questions.text: Which step in the viral replication cycle involves the conversion of viral single-stranded RNA into double-stranded DNA?
questions.solution:
• A) Uncoating: The process of releasing the viral genome from the capsid.
  • B) Biosynthesis: Refers to the replication and transcription of viral genomes and protein synthesis but does not specifically refer to the conversion of RNA to DNA.
  • C) Maturation and Assembly: The final stage where new viral particles are assembled and mature.
  • D) Reverse Transcription: A process used by retroviruses where their single-stranded RNA is converted into double-stranded DNA by the enzyme reverse transcriptase. This step is crucial for retroviruses like HIV.

Viral Replication Process: (SHORT NOTE)

  1. Adsorption:
    • The initial and most specific step in viral replication where the virus binds to specific receptors on the host cell. This step is crucial for the virus to recognize and attach to the appropriate host cell. If bypassed, viruses could potentially infect any cell.
  2. Penetration:
    • The virus enters the host cell. This step varies depending on the type of virus and the host cell.
  3. Uncoating:
    • The viral capsid is removed, and the viral genome is released into the host cell. Note that bacteriophages do not go through this step as their genetic material is injected directly into the host.
  4. Biosynthesis:
    • DNA Viruses: Generally replicate in the host cell nucleus (exception: Poxviruses, which replicate in the cytoplasm).
    • RNA Viruses: Typically replicate in the cytoplasm (exceptions: Orthomyxoviruses and Retroviruses).
    • Viral proteins are synthesized in the cytoplasm for both DNA and RNA viruses.
    • Positive-sense RNA Viruses: Their RNA serves directly as mRNA and is translated into proteins. Examples include Picornaviruses and Togaviruses.
    • Negative-sense RNA Viruses: Have RNA with polarity opposite to mRNA and require their own RNA polymerase to transcribe mRNA. Examples include Myxoviruses and Rabies.
    • Retroviruses: Use reverse transcriptase to convert their RNA into DNA, which then integrates into the host DNA.
  5. Maturation and Assembly:
    • Newly formed viral particles are assembled and mature within the host cell.
  6. Release:
    • Bacteriophages: Typically cause lysis of the host cell to release new virions.
    • Animal Viruses: Often released by budding (e.g., Myxoviruses) without causing cell lysis. Exceptions include Picornaviruses (lysis) and Varicella (cell-to-cell transmission).

Key Takeaway:

A process used by retroviruses where their single-stranded RNA is converted into double-stranded DNA by the enzyme reverse transcriptase. This step is crucial for retroviruses like HIV.

CDC Reference: CDC - Retroviruses

questions.text: Which type of RNA virus has its genetic material directly functioning as mRNA for protein synthesis?
questions.solution:
• A) Negative-sense RNA virus: Has RNA with polarity opposite to mRNA and requires RNA polymerase to transcribe mRNA. Examples of negative-sense RNA viruses include: Influenza Virus, Rabies Virus, Ebola Virus, Measles Virus, Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV)
  • B) Positive-sense RNA virus: The viral RNA genome acts directly as mRNA and can be translated directly into proteins. Examples include Picornaviridae and Togaviridae.
  • C) Retrovirus: Uses reverse transcription to convert its RNA into DNA, which then integrates into the host genome.
  • D) Double-stranded RNA virus: Includes viruses like Reoviridae that use their RNA in a different replication strategy.

Key Takeaway:

  • Recognizing positive-sense RNA viruses helps in understanding their direct translation into proteins and their rapid replication process.

CDC Reference: CDC - RNA Viruses

questions.text: What phenomenon describes the non-infectious viral particles that may result from defective assembly in high doses of influenza virus infection?
questions.solution:
• A) Eclipse phase: The period during which viruses cannot be detected inside the host cell, from penetration to the appearance of new virions.
  • B) Viropexis: The process of phagocytosis of virus particles by animal cells, not related to defective virus particles.
  • C) Von Magnus phenomenon: Refers to the production of non-infectious viral particles due to defective assembly, often observed in influenza virus infections at high doses.
  • D) Prion formation: Refers to infectious proteins without nucleic acids, distinct from the concept of defective viral particles.

Key Takeaway:

  • Von Magnus phenomena: A proportion of daughter viruses may not be infective (incomplete viruses) due to defective assembly. Usually seen when high dose of Influenza virus infecting a cell. The virus yield has high hemagglutinin titer but low infectivity.

CDC Reference: CDC - Influenza

questions.text: Examine the image of a cell culture with significant morphological changes. Which virus is likely responsible if the cells exhibit 'syncytium formation'?
questions.solution: Syncytium formation is a hallmark of certain viral infections, notably Measles Virus, which causes fusion of infected cells to form multinucleated giant cells.

questions.text: The image displays a cell culture showing 'Negri bodies' within the cytoplasm. Which virus is this most likely related to?
questions.solution:
Negri bodies are characteristic intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies associated with Rabies Virus infection.


KEY TAKE AWAY: Negri bodies are characteristic inclusion bodies seen in the cytoplasm of neurons infected with Rabies Virus. These bodies are eosinophilic and are a hallmark of rabies infection.

CDC Reference: For detailed information on Rabies and Negri bodies, visit CDC Rabies.

questions.text: In the provided image of a cell culture showing 'Cowdry A bodies', which virus is indicated?
questions.solution:
Cowdry A bodies are intranuclear inclusion bodies commonly associated with Herpes Simplex Virus infection.



Key Takeaway : Cowdry A bodies are intranuclear inclusion bodies associated with Herpes Simplex Virus. These bodies appear as large, eosinophilic inclusions within the nucleus of infected cells.

CDC Reference: For detailed information on Rabies and Negri bodies, visit CDC Herpes Simplex Virus

questions.text: Shows cells displaying 'Molluscum bodies'. Which virus is this associated with?
questions.solution:
Molluscum bodies are characteristic of infection with Molluscum Contagiosum Virus.

Key takeaway: The typical lesion appears dome-shaped, round, and pinkish-purple in colour.

questions.text: What type of viral detection involves observing the morphological changes of cells under a microscope?
questions.solution:
Cytopathic effect refers to the observable morphological changes in cells caused by viral infection.

  • Cytopathic Effects: Different viruses induce specific morphological changes in infected cells, which can be observed under a microscope.
  • Inclusion Bodies: Various viruses produce distinctive intracytoplasmic or intranuclear inclusion bodies that are used for identification.
  • Viral Cultivation: Viruses are cultured using various methods such as animal inoculation, egg inoculation, and tissue cultures, each suitable for different types of viruses.
  • Detection Methods: Techniques like PCR, immunofluorescence, and viral interference are essential for detecting viral growth and activity.

CDC Reference

For more detailed information on viral cultivation and detection methods, please refer to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) guidelines available at CDC Virology.

Key take away: Cytopathic effect (CPE) refers to the observable morphological changes in host cells caused by viral infection. This includes changes like cell rounding, syncytium formation, and cell lysis, which are used to identify and study viruses.

CDC Reference: For further reading on cytopathic effects, refer to CDC Virus Cultivation.

questions.text: Which virus is associated with the production of "Paschen bodies" as intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies?
questions.solution:
Paschen bodies are specific types of intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies that are characteristic of infection with Variola Virus, the causative agent of smallpox. These inclusion bodies appear as eosinophilic (pink-staining) masses in the cytoplasm of infected cells. Their presence is used diagnostically to identify smallpox infections.

  • Variola Virus: This virus causes smallpox, and the intracytoplasmic inclusions known as Paschen bodies are a classic diagnostic feature of this virus.
  • Fowl Pox Virus: Causes fowlpox in birds and is associated with intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies, but these are known as Bollinger bodies, not Paschen bodies.
  • Rabies Virus: Associated with Negri bodies, which are intracytoplasmic inclusions found in neurons infected with rabies.
  • Vaccinia Virus: This virus causes vaccinia (used in the smallpox vaccine) and is associated with Guarnieri bodies, not Paschen bodies.

CDC Reference: For more information on Paschen bodies and Variola Virus, refer to CDC Smallpox.

choices.text: For producing pocks and vaccine preparations
For direct observation of cytopathic effects

questions.text: What is the primary purpose of inoculating eggs in viral culture?
questions.solution:
Egg inoculation is a traditional method used in virology to propagate viruses and prepare vaccines. The various membranes in the egg (chorioallantoic membrane, yolk sac, amniotic membrane) are used depending on the type of virus and the desired outcome.

  • For producing pocks and vaccine preparations: The chorioallantoic membrane of the fertilized egg is used to produce pocks (lesions) for viruses like Vaccinia and Variola, and also for producing vaccines such as those for influenza and yellow fever.
  • For identifying bacterial contamination: Egg inoculation is not primarily used for this purpose.
  • For direct observation of cytopathic effects: Although cytopathic effects can be observed in egg cultures, this is not the primary purpose of inoculation.
  • For detecting viral antigens: Detection of viral antigens is typically done using immunological techniques rather than egg inoculation.
  • Key takeaways : Egg inoculation is primarily used for viral propagation and vaccine production, especially using the chorioallantoic membrane for vaccines.

CDC Reference: For detailed methods of viral culture and inoculation, see CDC Vaccine Production.

questions.text: Which virus is known for causing 'Crenation of cells and degeneration of the entire cell sheet' as a cytopathic effect?
questions.solution:
Adenovirus infection can lead to crenation and degeneration of the cell sheet, which are observable cytopathic effects.
Crenation and degeneration of the cell sheet are specific cytopathic effects observed in cells infected with Adenovirus. This effect involves the cell membrane becoming scalloped or crenated and eventually leading to cell death and detachment from the substrate.

  • Adenovirus: Known for causing a distinct cytopathic effect characterized by crenation of cells and degeneration of the cell sheet.
  • Measles Virus: Causes syncytium formation (fusion of cells) and other effects, but not crenation.
  • Herpes Simplex Virus: Typically causes large granular clumps and ballooning of cells.
  • Influenza Virus: Causes various cytopathic effects but is not known for causing crenation and cell sheet degeneration.

Key takeaways: Crenation and cell sheet degeneration are specific cytopathic effects of Adenovirus infection, leading to scalloped membranes and cell death.

CDC Reference: For more information on adenoviral infections and their cytopathic effects, see CDC Adenovirus.
